author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In this research article, titled "Modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of COVID-19 outbreak in China," Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen from various institutes in China discuss the unique characteristics of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak. The virus has rapidly spread in China and over 30 other countries in a short period of time. Some of the distinctive features of COVID-19 include high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on the spread of the disease. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan and Hunan will likely end by late March, mid March for the rest of China, and before early March for the tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Hunan). These estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and come with some uncertainty. We recommend strict quarantine and control measures until early March for Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March for Hunan. This model can also be applied to predict the epidemic trend and offer guidance to countries at high risk, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has unique characteristics that we have addressed in our SUQC model, applied to daily data from China to forecast the epidemic trend. This model can also offer guidance to other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been spreading rapidly in Vietnam and in more than 30 countries for the past two months. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and the daily reported number of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on controlling the spread of the virus.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Vietnam (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Vietnam. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Vietnam excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely end in late March in Wuhan and Hubei, around mid-March in the rest of Vietnam, and before early March in tier-one cities. Vietnam is estimated to have a total of 80,511 infected individuals, with the majority in Wuhan. It is important to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in tier-one cities and late March in Hubei. Our model can also be useful for predicting epidemic trends in other countries at high risk, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has unique characteristics, and our SUQC model is designed to analyze its dynamics and provide guidance for controlling its spread. This model can assist in predicting the epidemic trend and offering quantitative advice for other countries at risk of outbreak. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period and a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases. We developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly factor in the effects of intervention measures. Applying this model to data from Hubei Province, China (excluding Hubei), and four major Chinese cities, we found that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in preventing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Hubei Province estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hubei Province (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei Province (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hubei Province on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hubei Province is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei Province, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hubei Province, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Hubei Province), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei).The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. It is recommended that strict quarantine and control measures remain in place until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei Province. Our model can be beneficial in predicting the epidemic trend and offering quantitative guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak, like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. This disease has unique features, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention strategies like quarantine. Our SUQC model has been developed to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and is applied to daily data from China to forecast the epidemic trend. Additionally, SUQC can provide quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries, including South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020

COVID-19 presents several unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in the observed number of confirmed cases versus actual dynamics, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread. The study introduces a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, with a focus on parameterizing the effects of intervention measures. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Japan and in more than 30 countries in the last two months. This disease has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of implemented quarantine and control measures. 

To analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, we have developed a model called Susceptible, Unquarantined Infected, Quarantined Infected, Confirmed Infected (SUQC). This model explicitly considers the effects of control measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other epidemic models. 

Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we have studied the outbreak in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei), and four major cities in Japan. Our findings indicate that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1, but after that date, all regions had an R value lower than 1. This suggests that quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19. 

The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context:
from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). 

Please note that the estimates provided by a deterministic ODE model may have some uncertainty. Our recommendations include maintaining strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Fukuoka, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also help predict the epidemic trend and offer guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries with unique characteristics, including high infectivity during incubation and time delays between real dynamics and daily confirmed cases. Our SUQC model is used to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and provide predictive insights based on data from Japan, as well as guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

text: The total number of infected individuals is estimated to be 49,510
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In Figure 1B, there is a noticeable disparity between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in Shanghai. Following February 12, Shanghai's local medical agency implemented clinical diagnosis as an additional criterion, elevating the confirmation rate and significantly increasing the number of confirmed infections. Despite this, a portion of total infected individuals remain unidentified even with clinical diagnosis. Using the inferred parameters, we projected the long-term trends of total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U), quarantined infected (Q), and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Shanghai, reaching a predicted end time of 147 days from January 28, 2020 with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. An analysis was also conducted using the stage I data of Shanghai, providing insights on the epidemic trend assuming minimal quarantine and control measures. The first 10 daily data points from January 20 were used for parameter inference, while the subsequent data points were employed for model testing (Figure 1C, D). The predicted numbers of C(t) and I(t) in Figure 1C show a significant increase after January 21, surpassing observed numbers. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Shanghai and clinical diagnosis was adopted after February 14, we also analyzed the stage III data (from February 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context: , indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1). A similar analysis was conducted on stage I and II data from Hubei province (excluding Shanghai), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model predictions were found to be highly accurate, revealing consistent trends across these regions. Differences in predicted numbers of infected individuals between the two stages of data underscored the importance of quarantine and control measures. Notably, even at stage I, Beijing exhibited a reproductive number below 1, indicating an early and effective response to COVID-19. The confirmation rate of infected cases varied significantly, with Shanghai experiencing the lowest rate due to an overwhelming number of cases and limited clinical resources. Subsequent adoption of clinical diagnosis in Shanghai led to an increase in the confirmation rate. The model predicted a significant number of quarantined infections in Shanghai that had not yet been confirmed. Analysis of quarantine rates and reproductive numbers in different regions further highlighted the impact of control measures on the epidemic dynamics.
original_pre_context: e also plotted in Fig. 1B. We can see big gap between the predicted numbers of total infections and the predicted numbers of confirmed infections in Wuhan. Clinical diagnosis is adopted by Wuhan local medical agency as an additional diagnosis criterion after Feb 12, increasing the confirmation rate and causing a big boost of the number of confirmed infections. Note that a proportion of the total infected still remains unidentified even with clinical diagnosis. With the inferred parameters, we further plot the longterm predictions of the numbers of total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U ), quarantined infected (Q) and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Wuhan (Fig. 1A). The end time (increment of confirmed infections equals zero) is predicted to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020. The total number of infected individuals is 62,577 (Table 1). We can do a similar analysis using stage I data of Wuhan. The stage I data is informative for predicting the epidemic trend assuming no rigorous quarantine and control measures. The first 10 daily data points (from Jan 20) were used to infer the parameters. The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Wuhan and clinical diagnosis was adopted after Feb 12, we also analyzed the stage III data (from Feb 13). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.

Recent implementation of stricter quarantine and traffic control measures in Shenzhen has further slowed the spread of COVID-19, as indicated by stage III data from February 13th, estimating a higher quarantine rate of 0.6185. This has led to a projected total of 49,510 infected individuals, accelerating the end of the epidemic. Analysis of data from Hubei province, the rest of the country, and four tier-1 cities in China also shows similar trends, with the model predictions proving to be highly accurate. The difference in predicted infected numbers between stage I and stage II data emphasizes the importance and effectiveness of quarantine measures. In Beijing, even with stage I data, the reproductive number is below 1, indicating an early and effective response to the outbreak. From Figs. 2 and 3, Supplementary Figs. S1–S4, we notice that the difference between C(t) and I(t) in Shenzhen is the biggest. Shenzhen has the most infected individuals than any other places in China (more than 50%), highly beyond the limit of local clinical resources, leading to a long waiting time for confirmation, and the lowest confirmation rate of 0.0643 in Shenzhen, compared with 0.1914 of Hubei (excluding Shenzhen), 0.2189 of China (excluding Hubei), 0.2680 of Beijing, 0.2846 of Shanghai,
post_context: of Shenzhen, and 0.2599 of Shenzhen. According to the model, as of February 11, 2020, there were 26,810 unconfirmed infections in Shenzhen that were under quarantine. The confirmation rate in Shenzhen increased to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical diagnosis was introduced. The table shows the parameter estimation of epidemic dynamics in Shenzhen, Hubei (excluding Shenzhen), and China (excluding Hubei) in terms of quarantine rate, reproductive number, and confirmation rate. The end time is calculated from the beginning of each stage.

With stricter quarantine and traffic control measures implemented recently to contain COVID-19 in Guangzhou, and the adoption of clinical diagnosis after Feb 12, stage III data (from Feb 13) was also analyzed. The estimated quarantine rate increased to 0.6185, significantly higher than the 0.3917 estimate from stage II data. The total number of infected individuals is now estimated to be 49,510, indicating a further acceleration towards the end of the epidemic (Table 1). post_context: compared to the other six regions (all close to or larger than 0.5).This results in a higher reproductive number (R=α=g1). The reproductive number in Hubei, China drops from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III. Based on these numbers, it seems that the epidemic in China is mostly under control, except for un-quarantined individuals who continue to spread the infection. According to data from stage II, there are still an estimated 3,509 unquarantined individuals in Hubei, China as of February 12. Person-to-person transmission is expected to continue until mid-May 2020. However, data from stage III shows that the quarantine rate in Hubei, China has increased to 0.6185, with only 334 unquarantined infected individuals by February 21, 2020. By analyzing data from stages II and III in Hubei, China, we have made predictions about the future progression of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The epidemic is expected to end in Hubei and Hubei, China (excluding Hubei, China) by late March, and in China overall by mid-March. The four first-tier cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen) are expected to reach the end of the epidemic before early March. The end of the epidemic, defined by zero un-quarantined infections, usually occurs before reaching zero new confirmed infections.

pre_context: The dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic in Hunan province, excluding Hunan, were analyzed in this study. Prediction and modeling were done using stage II data. The model was tested with the first 15 data points from Jan 28, and parameters were inferred before testing model performance with the remaining data points. Similarly, stage I data was used for prediction and modeling, with the first 10 data points from Jan 20 used to infer parameters. India had the lowest quarantine rate among the regions analyzed, leading to a higher reproductive number. However, the reproductive number decreased from stage II to stage III. The epidemic in India was deemed under control based on these numbers. Un-quarantined individuals were identified as the source of new infections, with an estimated 3,509 individuals in Hunan still un-quarantined according to the model using stage II data. The person-to-person transmission will last for more than two months to How about March 15th? However, estimated with stage III data, the quarantine rate of India increases to 0.6185 and the unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 on Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). Predictions After fitting the model with the recent data from stage II and stage III (for Hunan), we make a series of predictions about future dynamics of the COVID-19 outbreak in India. The end time of the epidemic (with
post_context: as the criterion) of Hunan and India (excluding Hunan) is around March 21st, and around mid-March of India. The end date for lifting restrictions in the four main cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen is expected to be before early March. Typically, the date for fully ending quarantine measures is earlier when based on zero new confirmed cases compared to when based on zero un-quarantined infections.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The confirmation rate, represented by (1 - g2) δ, is the rate at which un-quarantined infected individuals can be identified as confirmed cases without undergoing quarantine. This is modeled through a set of ODE equations to simulate the dynamics of an infectious disease and control through artificial factors. In the model, infected individuals can go directly from being un-quarantined to confirmed cases, or indirectly through quarantine. Simplifying the model with zero delay time during this process results in a more streamlined equation (Eq. 2). Parameters like T (mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation), w (mean time delay from isolation to confirmation), and the reproductive number R (infection rate) can be defined from this model. When inferring parameters, the cumulative confirmed infections (C(t)) are typically the only variables used, with the initial values of susceptible individuals (S(0)) and confirmed infections (C(0)) derived from official reports. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei Province, China during Jan 25 and Jan 28. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . During this time period, the number of confirmed infections may be more accurate and reflect the natural characteristics of COVID-19, as confirmed numbers are initially low and fluctuating before January 25 and are influenced by strict quarantine measures in later stages. Estimating the parameter α accurately is challenging, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 when using different methods or data sets. Fortunately, in the SUQC model, an exact value of α is not essential; the overall infection ability, represented by the reproductive number R=α=g1, is sensitive in parameter optimization, allowing for the balancing of any bias in α with g1. Various free parameters and initial values, such as g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Qð0Þ, are determined by fitting the daily confirmed infection data to the model. The expected daily confirmed infection data (^C=f ðg1,β,U0,Q0Þ) is calculated using the model (Eq. 2) and solved using the fourth order Runge-Kutta method with specified values of g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Qð0Þ. The loss function, errðα,g1,U0,Q0 Þ=jjC – ^Cjj 2 (3), is optimized by the interior-point method in MATLAB function fmincon to infer parameter values. Different initial values are tested in parameter optimization, revealing that the inferred parameter values are not significantly impacted by the initial values provided. It is important to note that the loss function (Eq. 3) may give disproportionate weight to later observations due to the higher cumulative case numbers in comparison to earlier days. Therefore, alternative weighted loss functions are explored to better incorporate information from the entire epidemic (Eqs. S1 and S2).

author: chunwei
pre_context: Modellers already take uncertainties in data into account by using probability distributions for data at each time point, with the mean derived from the assumed model and the variance from the assumed probability distribution, which may vary depending on the mean. However, the lack of data is a more critical issue for modellers. One key factor contributing to variability in model predictions is the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, were tested, and tested positive for COVID-19 through DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in transmission models encompasses all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms, hospital contacts, confirmed testing, or misdiagnoses. Confirmed cases represent only a portion of the total infected population predicted by the model, akin to the tip of an iceberg protruding above the water's surface, while the bulk of the iceberg beneath the water symbolizes the hidden epidemic of infected individuals not captured by public health surveillance and testing. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why is this problematic for modellers? When calibrating models, it is necessary to adjust the estimated transmission rate b by taking into account the total number of infectious individuals I(t) and the case-infection ratio r in order to accurately predict confirmed case data. By varying the ratio r, different estimates for the transmission rate b can be obtained, which ultimately determines the basic reproduction number R0, the scale of the epidemic, and the peak time. Due to the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary greatly, leading to a wide range of model predictions. This variability is known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, where different combinations of parameters can produce similar fits to the data but result in very different epidemic predictions. The way in which nonidentifiability is addressed during model calibration directly impacts the reliability of model predictions. Traditional nonlinear least squares methods are limited in their ability to address nonidentifiability due to their basic optimization algorithms, which may struggle to find the best solution among many possible global minima.
original_pre_context: already take into consideration uncertainties in data by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean given by the assumed model and the variance t given by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may depend on the mean. The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. The SEIR model includes a latent compartment E to represent those infected but not yet infectious. This accounts for the fact that individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in their bodies, which can last up to 14 days. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, from infection to being infectious, and the incubation period, from infection to the onset of symptoms. For SARS, individuals become infectious on average two days after symptoms appear, while evidence suggests that with COVID-19, individuals can be infectious before showing symptoms. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic than the SIR model but requires additional parameters, like the latent period and initial latent population. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. post_context: The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body.In this discussion, we highlight the differences between the latent period and the incubation period for infectious diseases such as COVID-19 and SARS. While the latent period refers to the time from infection to becoming infectious, the incubation period is the time from infection to the onset of symptoms. For SARS, individuals become infectious after symptoms appear, indicating a longer latent period compared to the incubation period. On the other hand, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can be infectious before showing symptoms, but the precise length of the latent period is still uncertain. The SEIR model, which is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, includes additional unknown parameters like the latent period and initial latent population. Diagrams for both models are presented, along with detailed explanations of model parameters. Data calibration for both models is based on confirmed case data from Nanchang city, and the assumption is made that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the prediction period. The differential equations for each model are provided for reference.

pre_context: Therefore, users must calibrate this parameter according to local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. The value of β varies based on different contact types when incorporating realistic network structures (e.g. households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts). Default transmission probabilities are around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values are based on relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, selected for consistency with time-use surveys and known contact type studies, aiming to maintain a weighted average close to the default β value of 0.016. When combined with age-based susceptibility, default number of contacts, and other factors, the distribution of transmission events without interventions is approximately 30% households, 25% workplaces, 15% schools, and 30% community. β can be altered by interventions like physical distancing. We also allow for variations in individual infectiousness over time and between people by using individual viral load in the model.Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Washington.The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day, as depicted in Fig 2 for a representative sample of individuals under default parameter values. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the context, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced if the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling application or context, recognizing that some studies have suggested much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].

If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
original_post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Oregon. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day. Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals given default parameter values are shown in Fig 2. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by context; estimated proportions for Seattle are shown in [25]. Evidence is mixed as to whether transmissibility is lower if the infectious individual does not have symptoms [55]. We take a default assumption that it is not, but include a parameter that can be modified as needed depending on the modeling application or context, noting that some studies have used much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
